line_1: Her heaving breast unusual anguish wrung,
line_2: And never so persuasive was her tongue.

line_1: O'er her fair breast, by many sorrows wrung,
line_2: Her long light hair in waving tresses hung;

line_1: The sorer now your tender heart is wrung
line_2: So sings the sweetest Bard that ever sung;

line_1: The sorer now your tender heart is wrung
line_2: Ten thousand blessings on his tuneful tongue,

line_1: The sorer now your tender heart is wrung
line_2: When on the yielding Fair one's lips you hung;

line_1: The muse whose pensive soul with anguish wrung,
line_2: Her early lyre for thee has trembling strung;

line_1: "Ill can my breast, with keenest torture wrung,
line_2: "But ill bespeaks my faint and languid tongue,

line_1: While in despair his hands he wrung ....
line_2: And to the bark she, sighing, sprung.

line_1: Round her fair brow, her golden locks she wrung;
line_2: With rosy fingers, as uncurl'd they hung

line_1: The griefs my youthful breast have wrung
line_2: And dost thou ask my falt'ring tongue,

line_1: While with a father's anguish wrung,
line_2: He ceased: for now, by memory stung,
